member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Animation
member.summary: Represents a runtime animation instance that wraps engine-level animation functionality and provides high-level control over animation playback, timing, and state management.
member.remarks:
The Animation class serves as the primary interface for controlling individual animations in the game world. It bridges the gap between the low-level engine animation system () and the high-level game logic, providing a clean API for animation management.
Key features: - Priority-based animation management with automatic suppression - Smooth blending between animations with configurable timing - Real-time playback control (speed, looping, offset) - Event-driven state notifications - Automatic resource management and cleanup - Integration with the actor system for spatial coordination
Animation instances are typically created through interface methods rather than direct construction, ensuring proper integration with the actor lifecycle and animation management systems.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.AnimationBracket
member.summary: Represents a bracket animation controller that manages lifecycle-based animations following the Birth → Stand → Death pattern commonly used for temporary effects and actors.
member.remarks:
AnimationBracket provides a specialized animation controller for managing three-stage animation sequences that follow a predictable lifecycle pattern. This pattern is commonly used for: - Temporary visual effects that appear, persist, and disappear - Enemy spawn sequences with birth, idle, and death animations - Environmental objects with activation, active, and deactivation states - UI elements with show, display, and hide transitions
The bracket system automatically manages the transitions between stages and can be configured to either loop the stand animation indefinitely or play through all stages once (one-shot mode).
Key features: - Automatic stage progression with configurable timing - Support for both looping and one-shot playback modes - Optional actor destruction when the death animation completes - Integration with the priority-based animation system - Ability to skip the birth animation for immediate activation

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket
member.summary: Represents the configuration data for a bracket animation that manages lifecycle-based animations following the Birth → Stand → Death pattern.
member.remarks:
GameDataAnimationBracket provides configuration for three-stage animation sequences that follow a predictable lifecycle pattern. This is commonly used for: - Temporary visual effects that appear, persist, and disappear - Enemy or character spawn sequences - Environmental objects with activation, active, and deactivation states - UI elements with show, display, and hide transitions
The bracket system provides automatic management of stage transitions and supports both looping and one-shot playback modes, making it ideal for effects that need predictable lifecycle management.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.BirthStandDeathAnimation
member.summary: Gets or sets the birth, stand, and death animation configuration for this bracket.
member.value: The configuration containing the three animation stages.
member.remarks:
This property defines the three animation resources that will be used for each stage of the bracket animation lifecycle: - Birth: The initial animation played when the bracket starts - Stand: The looping animation played during the active phase - Death: The final animation played when the bracket ends
If this property is null, the bracket animation will not have any animations to play.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.LogicLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the logic layer that this bracket animation will be played on.
member.value: The animation logic layer. Default is .
member.remarks: Logic layers provide a way to categorize animations and control their interactions. Bracket animations on different logic layers can play simultaneously without interfering with each other, while animations on the same layer compete based on priority.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.Priority
member.summary: Gets or sets the priority of this bracket animation.
member.value: The priority value, where higher numbers indicate higher priority. Default is 0.
member.remarks:
Animation priority determines which animation is visible when multiple animations are playing on the same actor and logic layer. Higher priority bracket animations will suppress lower priority animations, causing them to be paused until the higher priority animation completes or is stopped.
The priority applies to all stages of the bracket animation (birth, stand, and death).

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.ForceOneShot
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the bracket should play all stages once (one-shot mode) or loop the stand animation indefinitely.
member.value: True for one-shot mode (Birth → Stand → Death); false for looping mode (Birth → Stand loop → Death on stop).
member.remarks:
When set to true, the bracket will play through all three stages sequentially: Birth animation → Stand animation (once) → Death animation, then stop.
When set to false, the bracket will play the Birth animation once, then loop the Stand animation indefinitely until manually stopped, at which point the Death animation will play.
One-shot mode is useful for effects with predetermined durations, while looping mode is ideal for effects that need to persist until external conditions change.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.KillOnFinish
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the associated actor should be destroyed when the bracket animation completes.
member.value: True to destroy the actor when the animation completes; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
When set to true, the actor associated with this bracket animation will be automatically destroyed when the death animation completes. This is useful for temporary effects, spawned enemies, or other actors that should be cleaned up when their animation lifecycle ends.
When set to false, the actor will remain in the scene after the animation completes, allowing it to be reused or controlled by other systems.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.SkipBirthAnimation
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the birth animation should be skipped.
member.value: True to skip the birth animation and start directly with the stand animation; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
When set to true, the bracket will skip the birth animation and immediately begin playing the stand animation. This is useful when you want the effect to appear instantly without any spawn/appear animation.
This setting is particularly useful for effects that need to be synchronized with other systems or when the birth animation is not needed for the desired visual effect.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationBracket.CachePlayParam
member.summary: Gets the cached animation bracket play parameters constructed from this configuration.
member.value: The cached instance.
member.remarks:
This property provides a cached version of the bracket animation parameters that can be used directly with the animation system without needing to construct new parameter objects each time. The cache is lazily initialized and reused for performance.
The cached parameters include all the configuration settings from this bracket, including the birth/stand/death animation names, priority, logic layer, and behavioral flags.
TODO: The cache should be invalidated and rebuilt when animation parameters change. Currently, changes to the configuration properties will not automatically update the cached parameters.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSequence
member.summary: Represents a comprehensive animation sequence configuration that orchestrates multiple animation playbacks, actor creations, and event triggers over time to create complex, synchronized animation experiences.
member.remarks:
GameDataAnimationSequence serves as a high-level animation composition tool that allows you to: - Orchestrate multiple animation playbacks with precise timing and blending - Spawn and manage temporary actors during specific moments in the sequence - Trigger events at designated time offsets for game logic integration
This class is particularly useful for creating cutscenes, complex ability animations, environmental sequences, or any scenario where multiple visual and gameplay elements need to be synchronized with precise timing control.
The sequence execution follows this pattern: 1. Animation playbacks are initiated according to their individual timing configurations 2. Sequence actors are created at their specified spawn offsets and remain active for their configured durations 3. Sequence events are triggered at their designated time offsets 4. All elements are coordinated to create a cohesive, synchronized experience

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSequence.Playbacks
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of animation playbacks that will be executed during the sequence.
member.value: A list of configurations that define how animations are played within the sequence.
member.remarks: The playbacks in this collection are processed according to the sequential order.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSequence.SequenceActors
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of actors that will be dynamically created and managed during the animation sequence.
member.value: A list of configurations that define when and how actors are spawned during the sequence.
member.remarks:
Sequence actors provide a way to dynamically spawn temporary visual or gameplay elements that are synchronized with the animation timeline. These actors are automatically created at their specified and remain active for their specified .
All sequence actors are automatically attached to the parent actor that is playing the sequence, ensuring proper spatial relationships and lifecycle management. This is ideal for effects like: - Particle systems that should appear during specific moments - Temporary visual elements like magic circles or weapon trails - Supporting actors that enhance the main animation sequence

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSequence.SequenceEvents
member.summary: Gets or sets the collection of events that will be triggered at specific time offsets during the animation sequence.
member.value: A list of configurations that define when and what events are triggered during the sequence.
member.remarks:
Sequence events provide integration points between the animation system and game logic, allowing the sequence to communicate with other systems at precise moments. Events are triggered based on their relative to the sequence start time.
Events can optionally pause the sequence execution using , which is useful for creating interactive moments or waiting for external conditions before continuing.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple
member.summary: Represents the configuration data for a simple animation that can be played on game actors.
member.remarks:
GameDataAnimationSimple provides all the necessary configuration parameters for playing a single animation with specific timing, priority, and blending characteristics. This class serves as the data definition that is used to create instances at runtime.
The configuration includes: - Animation resource file reference - Playback parameters (speed, looping, timing) - Priority and layer settings for animation conflict resolution - Blending parameters for smooth transitions - Body part targeting for partial animation support
This class is typically used in game data files and can be referenced by actors or other systems that need to play animations with consistent parameters.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.File
member.summary: Gets or sets the animation resource file that will be played.
member.value: The animation resource file reference.
member.remarks: This property specifies the actual animation file that will be loaded and played when this animation configuration is used. The file should be a valid animation resource that has been imported into the game's resource system.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.LogicLayer
member.summary: Gets or sets the logic layer that this animation will be played on.
member.value: The animation logic layer. Default is .
member.remarks:
Logic layers provide a way to categorize animations and control their interactions. Animations on different logic layers can play simultaneously without interfering with each other, while animations on the same layer compete based on priority.
Common layer usage: - Normal: Standard gameplay animations - Additive: Overlay animations that blend with other animations - Override: High-priority animations that override others

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.Priority
member.summary: Gets or sets the priority of this animation.
member.value: The priority value, where higher numbers indicate higher priority. Default is 0.
member.remarks:
Animation priority determines which animation is visible when multiple animations are playing on the same actor and logic layer. Higher priority animations will suppress lower priority animations, causing them to be paused until the higher priority animation completes or is stopped.
Priority values are typically organized as follows: - 0-50: Idle and ambient animations - 51-100: Movement animations - 101-200: Action animations - 201+: Critical or override animations

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.BodyPart
member.summary: Gets or sets the body part that this animation affects.
member.value: The body part specification. Default is .
member.remarks:
Body part specification allows for partial animation support where different parts of the character can be animated independently. This enables complex animation blending scenarios such as: - Upper body combat animations while lower body continues walking - Facial expressions independent of body movement - Separate arm animations for dual-wielding characters
FullBody animations will affect the entire character model, while specific body part animations will only affect their designated portions.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.Speed
member.summary: Gets or sets the playback speed multiplier for this animation.
member.value: The speed multiplier, where 1.0 is normal speed. Default is 1.0.
member.remarks:
This property controls the playback speed of the animation. Values less than 1.0 slow down the animation, while values greater than 1.0 speed it up. The speed affects the entire animation timeline proportionally.
Common speed values: - 0.5: Half speed (slow motion effect) - 1.0: Normal speed - 1.5: 50% faster - 2.0: Double speed
Speed can be changed at runtime through the Animation instance after playback begins.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.BlendIn
member.summary: Gets or sets the blend-in time for smooth transitions when this animation becomes active.
member.value: The blend-in duration. Default is 0.15 seconds.
member.remarks:
The blend-in time determines how smoothly this animation transitions in when it becomes the active animation. This occurs in several scenarios: - When this animation starts playing and needs to blend from a previous animation - When this animation resumes after being suppressed by a higher priority animation - When this animation's priority is dynamically changed, causing it to become active
During the blend-in period, the animation system will smoothly interpolate between the previous animation state and this animation, creating a natural transition without abrupt changes.
Setting this to zero will cause immediate switching with no transition period. Longer blend times create smoother transitions but may delay the visual impact of the new animation.
member.example: A typical use case: If a character has a sleeping animation and a standing animation, but no specific transition animation between them, you can set a longer blend-in time (like 2 seconds) for the sleeping animation. This will cause the character to smoothly transition from standing to lying down over 2 seconds, effectively creating a low-cost transition animation.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.StartOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the time offset from the beginning of the animation where playback should start.
member.value: The start offset duration. Default is zero (start from beginning).
member.remarks:
This property allows you to skip the initial portion of an animation and start playback from a specific point in the timeline. This is useful for: - Skipping slow wind-up portions of animations - Starting animations at their most impactful moments - Synchronizing animations with external events - Creating variations of the same animation with different starting points
The offset is measured from the beginning of the animation, so an offset of 1 second will skip the first second of the animation and begin playback from the 1-second mark.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.IsLooping
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this animation should loop continuously.
member.value: True if the animation should loop; otherwise, false. Default is false.
member.remarks:
When set to true, the animation will automatically restart from the beginning when it reaches the end, creating a continuous loop. This is commonly used for: - Idle animations that should repeat indefinitely - Environmental animations like flowing water or spinning objects - Background animations that provide continuous movement
When set to false, the animation will play once and then stop, which is appropriate for: - One-time actions like attacks or spell casting - Transition animations between states - Cutscene animations with specific timing requirements
The looping behavior can be changed at runtime through the Animation instance.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.GameDataAnimationSimple.CachePlayParam
member.summary: Gets the cached animation play parameters constructed from this configuration.
member.value: The cached instance.
member.remarks:
This property provides a cached version of the animation parameters that can be used directly with the animation system without needing to construct new parameter objects each time. The cache is lazily initialized and reused for performance.
TODO: The cache should be invalidated and rebuilt when animation parameters change. Currently, changes to the configuration properties will not automatically update the cached parameters.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceActorSpawn
member.summary: Represents a configuration for spawning and managing a temporary actor during an animation sequence, defining what actor to spawn, when to spawn it, and how long it should exist.
member.remarks:
SequenceActorSpawn provides precise temporal control over actor lifecycle within animation sequences. This enables the creation of synchronized visual effects, temporary objects, and supporting elements that enhance the main animation with perfect timing coordination.
The spawned actor will be automatically attached to the parent actor playing the sequence, ensuring proper spatial relationships and automatic cleanup when the sequence completes.
Common use cases include: - Particle effects that appear during specific animation moments - Temporary visual elements like magic circles, auras, or weapon trails - Supporting actors that provide context or enhancement to the main animation - Environmental effects synchronized with character actions

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceActorSpawn.Actor
member.summary: Gets or sets the actor configuration that will be spawned during the animation sequence.
member.value: A game data link to the that defines the actor to be spawned.
member.remarks:
This property references the actor definition that will be instantiated and attached to the parent actor playing the sequence. The spawned actor will inherit spatial positioning from the parent and will be automatically managed throughout its lifecycle.
The actor can be any valid game actor including visual effects, temporary objects, UI elements, or complex nested actor hierarchies that enhance the animation sequence.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceActorSpawn.SpawnOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the time offset from the animation sequence start when this actor should be spawned.
member.value: The time span representing when the actor spawning should occur relative to the sequence beginning. Default is zero (spawn immediately).
member.remarks:
This offset allows precise synchronization of actor spawning with specific moments in the animation sequence. A value of zero means the actor spawns immediately when the sequence starts, while positive values delay the spawn until that time offset is reached.
The timing is calculated from the sequence start time, not from any individual animation playback within the sequence, ensuring consistent timing regardless of animation complexity.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceActorSpawn.Duration
member.summary: Gets or sets how long the spawned actor should remain active and visible in the sequence.
member.value: The time span representing the total lifetime of the spawned actor. Default is zero (instantaneous).
member.remarks:
This duration controls the total lifespan of the spawned actor from its spawn time. The actor will be automatically despawned (destroyed) when this duration expires, calculated from the time.
For example, if SpawnOffset is 2 seconds and Duration is 3 seconds, the actor will: - Spawn at 2 seconds into the sequence - Remain active for 3 seconds - Be automatically despawned at 5 seconds into the sequence
A duration of zero creates an instantaneous effect that spawns and immediately despawns, which can be useful for one-time triggers or very brief visual effects.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceEvent
member.summary: Represents a timed event that will be triggered at a specific moment during an animation sequence, providing integration points between the animation system and game logic.
member.remarks:
SequenceEvent enables precise synchronization between visual animations and gameplay mechanics by allowing events to be triggered at exact time offsets within an animation sequence. This creates opportunities for perfect timing coordination between animations and game systems.
Events can optionally pause the sequence execution, which is useful for creating interactive moments, waiting for external conditions, or ensuring critical timing dependencies are met before the sequence continues.
Common use cases include: - Triggering sound effects at specific animation moments - Applying damage or healing at precise timing during ability animations - Signaling animation phase completions to other game systems - Creating synchronization points for multiplayer or networked scenarios - Triggering particle effects or environmental changes - Notifying UI systems of animation milestones

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceEvent.EventKey
member.summary: Gets or sets the event key that identifies which event will be triggered when this sequence event activates.
member.value: A that specifies which event should be triggered by the animation system.
member.remarks:
This event key serves as the strongly-typed identifier that game systems will use to respond to the triggered event. Using an enum-based key system provides better type safety, IntelliSense support, and prevents typos compared to string-based event names.
Event keys are used by event aggregators, message systems, or direct event handlers to determine what action should be taken when the event is triggered at the specified timing. The enum-based approach ensures compile-time validation of event types.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceEvent.Offset
member.summary: Gets or sets the time offset from the animation sequence start when this event should be triggered.
member.value: The time span representing when the event should be triggered relative to the sequence beginning. Default is zero (trigger immediately).
member.remarks:
This offset provides precise timing control for event triggering within the animation sequence. A value of zero means the event triggers immediately when the sequence starts, while positive values delay the event trigger until that time offset is reached.
The timing is calculated from the sequence start time, ensuring consistent event timing regardless of the complexity or number of animation playbacks within the sequence. This allows for reliable synchronization between visual animations and gameplay events.

member.name: P:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Data.Struct.SequenceEvent.PauseSequence
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the animation sequence should pause execution when this event is triggered.
member.value: true if the sequence should pause when this event triggers; otherwise, false. Default is false.
member.remarks:
When set to true, this property causes the entire animation sequence to pause execution when the event is triggered, allowing for interactive moments or external condition dependencies. The sequence will remain paused until explicitly resumed by external game logic.
This feature is particularly useful for: - Creating interactive cutscenes that wait for player input - Synchronizing with external systems that may have variable timing - Implementing conditional animation flows based on game state - Ensuring critical events are properly processed before animation continues
When false (default), the event is triggered and the sequence continues normal execution without interruption, suitable for fire-and-forget events like sound effects or damage application.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Enum.BracketStage
member.summary: Specifies the stages of a bracket animation lifecycle.
member.remarks: BracketStage represents the different phases that a bracket animation goes through during its lifecycle. Each stage corresponds to a specific animation that is played during that phase of the bracket's execution.

member.name: F:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Enum.BracketStage.Stopped
member.summary: Represents a state where the operation has been stopped.
member.remarks: This value is typically used to indicate that the animation is no longer running on the actor, basically destroyed.

member.name: F:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Enum.BracketStage.None
member.summary: No specific stage is active or the bracket is not running.

member.name: F:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Enum.BracketStage.Birth
member.summary: The birth stage, where the initial spawn/appear animation is played.
member.remarks: This stage is typically used for spawn effects, appearance animations, or any initial visual effect that introduces the object to the scene. The birth animation is played once when the bracket starts (unless skipped).

member.name: F:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Enum.BracketStage.Stand
member.summary: The stand stage, where the main/idle animation is played.
member.remarks: This stage represents the active phase of the bracket animation. Depending on the configuration, the stand animation may loop indefinitely or play once before proceeding to the death stage. This is typically used for idle animations, sustained effects, or looping behaviors.

member.name: F:GameCore.ModelAnimation.Enum.BracketStage.Death
member.summary: The death stage, where the final despawn/disappear animation is played.
member.remarks: This stage is used for destruction effects, disappearance animations, or any final visual effect before the bracket completes. The death animation is played once when the bracket is stopped or completes its cycle. After the death animation, the bracket may destroy the associated actor if configured to do so.

member.name: T:GameCore.ModelAnimation.IAnimationSwingController
member.summary: Controller for animations that have the abstract concept of preswing, swing, and backswing stages. Typically used for ability casting and melee attacks.

member.name: T:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.ShadowType
member.summary: 定义阴影渲染的类型，控制游戏对象的阴影生成方式
member.remarks: 阴影类型决定了游戏对象如何产生和显示阴影效果。不同的阴影类型在性能和视觉质量之间提供了不同的平衡， 允许开发者根据游戏需求和设备性能选择合适的阴影实现方式。

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.ShadowType.FakeShadow
member.summary: 假阴影 - 使用预制的平面阴影贴图，性能开销最小
member.remarks: 使用简单的平面投影或预制阴影贴图来模拟阴影效果。 这种方式性能开销很小，但视觉效果相对简单，适用于低端设备或大量对象的场景。

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.ShadowType.DeviceDependentShadow
member.summary: 设备依赖阴影 - 根据设备性能自动选择阴影实现方式
member.remarks: 根据设备的渲染能力自动选择阴影类型。如果设备支持动态阴影，将使用动态阴影； 否则降级为平面阴影。这种方式提供了最佳的性能与质量平衡，适应不同设备的能力。

member.name: T:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SliceMode
member.summary: Defines the mode for specifying animation slice duration.
member.remarks: SliceMode determines how the animation slice end point is calculated: - Duration: Uses start offset and duration length for precise time-based slicing - EndOffset: Uses start offset and absolute end offset for position-based slicing - EndOffsetFromEnd: Uses start offset and offset from animation end for relative slicing This provides flexibility in animation content selection and timing control.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SliceMode.Duration
member.summary: Specify start offset and duration length.
member.remarks: Uses StartOffset and SliceDuration to define the animation slice. The slice runs from StartOffset for the specified SliceDuration. This is the most straightforward way to specify a time-based slice.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SliceMode.EndOffset
member.summary: Specify start offset and end offset.
member.remarks: Uses StartOffset and EndOffset to define the animation slice. The slice runs from StartOffset to EndOffset within the original animation. This allows for absolute positioning within the animation timeline.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SliceMode.EndOffsetFromEnd
member.summary: Specify start offset and end offset from the end of the original animation.
member.remarks: Uses StartOffset and EndOffsetFromEnd to define the animation slice. The slice runs from StartOffset to (animation_end - EndOffsetFromEnd). This is useful when you want to exclude a specific amount of time from the animation end.

member.name: T:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory
member.summary: Defines categories for organizing and managing different types of sounds in the game.
member.remarks: This enum is used to classify sounds for purposes such as volume control, mixing, and resource management. Each category represents a different type of audio content.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.UI
member.summary: User interface sounds such as button clicks, menu navigation, and notifications.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Ambient
member.summary: Background environmental sounds that create atmosphere.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Music
member.summary: Background music and musical compositions.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Cutscene
member.summary: Audio for cinematic sequences and story scenes.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Dialogue
member.summary: Character speech and conversation audio.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Alert
member.summary: Warning sounds and alert notifications.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Movement
member.summary: Sounds related to character and object movement.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Foley
member.summary: Sound effects for everyday actions and interactions.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Doodad
member.summary: Environmental object and decoration sounds.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Combat
member.summary: Battle, fighting, and combat-related audio effects.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Message
member.summary: System messages and communication sounds.

member.name: F:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Enum.SoundCategory.Voice
member.summary: Character voice acting and vocal expressions.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataModel.AssetLayerScale
member.summary: Represents the scale of the asset layer, acting as an independent scaling factor separate from the script scale. This ensures that assets imported from different tools are scaled consistently, so the users don't need to adjust script scales manually based on the tool used in writing the gameplay script.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataModel.ApplyAssetLayerScaleToChildren
member.summary: Determines whether the asset layer scale should be applied to child elements, affecting the scaling behavior of nested components. By default, this should be set to false to adhere to the original design principle of the Asset Layer Scale, which is intended to apply only to the asset itself.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataModel.ForceOffScreenUpdate
member.summary: Indicates whether to force an update when the object is off-screen. Useful for ensuring updates occur even when not visible.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataModel.SimpleBoundingCylinder
member.summary: Represents an optional simple bounding cylinder for simple ray-casting.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataParticle.AssetLayerScale
member.summary: Represents the scale of the asset layer, acting as an independent scaling factor separate from the script scale. This ensures that assets imported from different tools are scaled consistently, so the users don't need to adjust script scales manually based on the tool used in writing the gameplay script.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataParticle.ApplyAssetLayerScaleToChildren
member.summary: Determines whether the asset layer scale should be applied to child elements, affecting the scaling behavior of nested components. By default, this should be set to false to adhere to the original design principle of the Asset Layer Scale, which is intended to apply only to the asset itself.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataSound.FadeTime
member.summary: Normal sound usually has a fade time of 0.5 seconds, while music has a fade time of 2 seconds.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.GameDataSound.Category
member.summary: Represents the category of sound, which can be used to group or classify sounds for various purposes, such as muting or adjusting volume levels based on the category.

member.name: T:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationMapping
member.summary: Represents a mapping relationship between a logical animation alias and an actual animation resource, enabling the use of meaningful names instead of direct file paths in animation systems.
member.remarks:
AnimationMapping provides an abstraction layer for animation resources by allowing developers to: - Use logical names (aliases) like "walk", "attack", "idle" instead of file paths - Easily swap animation files without changing code that references the animations - Organize animations with consistent naming across different models and contexts - Support multiple aliases pointing to the same animation resource for reusability
This mapping system is particularly useful in game development where animation files may be reorganized, renamed, or replaced during development, and where different models may use different animation files for the same logical action.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationMapping.AnimationAlias
member.summary: Gets or sets the logical alias name used to reference this animation in code.
member.value: A meaningful name that represents the animation's purpose or action, such as "walk", "attack", or "idle".
member.remarks:
This alias serves as the public interface for the animation, allowing developers to use descriptive names instead of file paths. The alias should be consistent across different models that perform the same logical action, enabling code reuse and maintainability.
Common naming conventions include: - Action-based: "walk", "run", "attack", "defend" - State-based: "idle", "casting", "stunned", "dead" - Context-specific: "intro", "victory", "defeat"

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationMapping.AnimationRaw
member.summary: Gets or sets the actual animation resource that will be played when the alias is referenced.
member.value: The animation file or resource path that contains the actual animation data.
member.remarks:
This property points to the concrete animation resource (typically a file) that will be loaded and played when the corresponding alias is requested. The raw animation can be: - A file path to an animation file (e.g., "animations/character_walk.fbx") - A reference to an animation resource in the game's asset system - Any valid Animation resource identifier
Multiple mappings can reference the same AnimationRaw, allowing for animation reuse across different aliases or contexts.

member.name: T:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback
member.summary: Represents a comprehensive animation playback configuration that controls how an animation is played back, including timing, scaling, looping, and blending behavior.
member.remarks: AnimationPlayback provides fine-grained control over animation playback by allowing you to: - Reference a source animation and apply time scaling - Define slice configuration using different modes (duration, end offset, or end offset from end) - Control looping behavior when playback duration exceeds content duration - Configure smooth blending transitions for seamless animation transitions This class is particularly useful for creating complex animation sequences, dynamic timing adjustments, and smooth animation blending in game scenarios.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.AnimationRaw
member.summary: Gets or sets the source animation to be played back.
member.value: The animation resource that will be used as the source for playback.
member.remarks: This property references the raw animation data that will be modified according to the other playback configuration properties in this class.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.Scale
member.summary: Gets or sets the time scale multiplier applied to the original animation speed.
member.value: The speed multiplier where 1.0 is normal speed, values greater than 1.0 speed up playback, and values less than 1.0 slow down playback. Default is 1.0.
member.remarks: This scale factor affects the overall playback speed of the animation. For example: - 0.5 will play the animation at half speed - 2.0 will play the animation at double speed The scale is applied to the original animation timing before other duration calculations.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode for specifying the animation slice.
member.value: The slice mode that determines how the slice end point is specified. Default is Duration.
member.remarks: This mode determines which properties are used to define the animation slice: - Duration: Uses StartOffset and SliceDuration - EndOffset: Uses StartOffset and EndOffset - EndOffsetFromEnd: Uses StartOffset and EndOffsetFromEnd

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.StartOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the start offset for the animation playback, based on the original animation speed.
member.value: The time offset from the beginning of the source animation where playback should start.
member.remarks: This offset allows you to start playback from any point within the source animation, effectively skipping the initial portion. The offset is calculated based on the original animation timing before any scaling is applied.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.SliceDuration
member.summary: Gets or sets the duration of the animation content to be played, based on the original animation speed. Used when Mode is set to Duration.
member.value: The length of time from the source animation that should be included in this playback configuration.
member.remarks: This duration defines how much of the source animation (starting from the StartOffset) will be considered for playback. It represents the "slice" of animation content before any scaling or playback duration modifications are applied. Only used when Mode is SliceMode.Duration.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.EndOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the end offset for the animation slice, based on the original animation speed. Used when Mode is set to EndOffset.
member.value: The time offset from the beginning of the source animation where the slice should end.
member.remarks: This end offset defines the absolute end point of the animation slice within the source animation. The effective slice duration will be (EndOffset - StartOffset). Only used when Mode is SliceMode.EndOffset.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.EndOffsetFromEnd
member.summary: Gets or sets the end offset from the end of the original animation, based on the original animation speed. Used when Mode is set to EndOffsetFromEnd.
member.value: The time offset from the end of the source animation where the slice should end.
member.remarks: This end offset defines how much time before the end of the original animation the slice should stop. For example, if the original animation is 10 seconds and EndOffsetFromEnd is 2 seconds, the slice will end at 8 seconds from the start. Only used when Mode is SliceMode.EndOffsetFromEnd.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.IsLooping
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the animation should loop when the playback duration exceeds the slice duration.
member.value: true if the animation should loop; otherwise, false. Default is false.
member.remarks: When the PlaybackDuration is longer than the effective slice duration, this property controls the behavior: - If true, the animation will loop continuously until the PlaybackDuration is reached - If false, the animation will pause at the last frame until the PlaybackDuration is reached

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.PlaybackDuration
member.summary: Gets or sets the actual playback duration of the animation at the scaled animation speed.
member.value: The total time that the animation playback should last, accounting for scaling and timing adjustments.
member.remarks: This duration controls the total time the animation will play, independent of the source content duration. The behavior depends on the relationship between PlaybackDuration and the effective slice duration: - If PlaybackDuration is less than slice duration: animation stops early - If PlaybackDuration is greater than slice duration: animation loops (if IsLooping is true) or pauses at the last frame - If PlaybackDuration equals slice duration: animation plays exactly once through the slice content

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.BlendIn
member.summary: Gets or sets the blend-in duration for smooth transitions when starting this animation.
member.value: The time span over which the animation will blend in from the previous animation state. Default is 0.15 seconds.
member.remarks: This property controls how smoothly the animation transitions in when it starts playing. A longer blend-in duration creates a more gradual transition, while a shorter duration creates a more abrupt change. This is particularly useful for character animations where sudden transitions can look unnatural.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.AnimationPlayback.BlendOut
member.summary: Gets or sets the blend-out duration for smooth transitions when ending this animation.
member.value: The time span over which the animation will blend out to the next animation state. Default is 0.15 seconds.
member.remarks: This property controls how smoothly the animation transitions out when it finishes playing. A longer blend-out duration creates a more gradual transition to the next animation, while a shorter duration creates a more abrupt change. This helps create seamless animation sequences and prevents jarring transitions between different animations.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.StatusBarPosition.RootZOffset
member.summary: The StatusBar's position relative to the root bone.

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Data.Struct.StatusBarPosition.ScreenOffset
member.summary: This is device-dependent, a offset in screen space.

member.name: T:GameCore.ResourceType.Icon
member.summary: 表示游戏中的图标资源，包装图标文件路径并提供类型转换功能

member.name: M:GameCore.ResourceType.Icon.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: 表示游戏中的图标资源，包装图标文件路径并提供类型转换功能
member.param: 图标文件的路径
member.remarks: 此结构体用于表示和管理游戏中的图标资源，通常用于 UI 元素、物品图标、技能图标等。 支持与字符串类型的隐式转换，便于在不同的上下文中使用图标路径。 图标通常是小尺寸的图像文件，用于在用户界面中提供视觉标识。

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Icon.Path
member.summary: 获取或设置图标文件的路径

member.name: P:GameCore.ResourceType.Icon.FileName
member.summary: 获取或设置图标文件的名称

member.name: P:GameCore.OrderSystem.Command.IsRequest
member.summary: Request commands must have a player, and the player must be able to control the entity. The player also must be able to see the target if the target is an entity. The ability cannot be a hidden ability.

member.name: P:GameCore.OrderSystem.Command.IsAcquired
member.summary: Acquired commands are auto-acquired commands like auto-casting and recasting. When orders queued after an acquired command, the acquired command will be removed, unless it is in uninterruptible state. Interrupting of acquired commands only consider the uninterruptible state, not the order stage or interrupting priority.

member.name: F:GameCore.OrderSystem.CommandFlag.Queued
member.summary: Queued command.

member.name: F:GameCore.OrderSystem.CommandFlag.Preempt
member.summary: Preempt the current command queue.

member.name: F:GameCore.OrderSystem.CommandFlag.IsAcquired
member.summary: Auto-acquired commands that are auto-casting or recasting commands.

member.name: F:GameCore.OrderSystem.CommandFlag.IsRequest
member.summary: Is request command from player client or AI.

member.name: F:GameCore.OrderSystem.CommandFlag.IsUser
member.summary: Is user request command from player client.

member.name: F:GameCore.OrderSystem.CommandFlag.IsAI
member.summary: Is AI request command from AI.

member.name: P:GameCore.OrderSystem.Order.IsRequest
member.summary: Request commands must have a player, and the player must be able to control the owner of the order. The player also must be able to see the approach target if the target is an entity. The ability cannot be a hidden ability.

member.name: M:GameCore.OrderSystem.Order.ThinkIsInArc
member.summary: Used for pre-validation before preswing stage.

member.name: M:GameCore.OrderSystem.Order.ThinkIsInArcSlop
member.summary: Used for casting and channeling stage.

member.name: P:GameCore.OrderSystem.OrderAbilityActive.AbilityCache
member.summary: Snapshotted upon preswing.

member.name: P:GameCore.OrderSystem.OrderAbilityActive.AbilityPhase
member.summary: Snapshotted upon preswing.

member.name: M:GameCore.OrderSystem.OrderAbilityActive.FilterCaster
member.summary: You can issue order to other unit's ability if you are a validated caster to that ability. Most of the time, host of the ability is always a valid caster, except for Interact Ability.

member.name: M:GameCore.OrderSystem.OrderAbilityActive.TotalCastingTime
member.summary: Calculates the complete casting time for the ability, including all phases (preswing, cast, channel, and backswing). This represents the theoretical duration if all phases execute without interruption.
member.returns: A representing the complete casting time. Returns if the ability is transient. When is set, returns the normalized duration plus scaled backswing time.

remarks.para:
This method is primarily used by systems that need to know the complete theoretical casting duration:
Animation system: To determine if animation events should be sent to clients
UI system: To display casting progress bars or cooldown timers
Effect duration: For abilities that need to know their full execution time
Important: This duration may differ from the actual attack interval for abilities with and interruptible backswing, where subsequent attacks can interrupt the backswing phase before completion.

member.name: T:GameCore.OrderSystem.OrderStop
member.summary: Clear up the order queue

member.name: M:GameCore.OrderSystem.OrderStop.#ctor(GameCore.OrderSystem.Command)
member.summary: Clear up the order queue

member.remarks: This enum represents mouse buttons and other pointer device buttons (such as touch screen) that can be pressed simultaneously. Multiple buttons can be combined using bitwise operations to represent complex input states. The buttons are numbered from 1 to 32, with additional special values for common operations.

member.name: T:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerRelationShip
member.summary: Defines the relationship types between players in the game.
member.remarks: This enum is used to determine how players interact with each other, affecting gameplay mechanics such as combat, visibility, and cooperation.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerRelationShip.Enemy
member.summary: Players are hostile to each other and can attack one another.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerRelationShip.Neutral
member.summary: Players have no special relationship - neither hostile nor friendly.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerRelationShip.Ally
member.summary: Players are allied and typically cannot harm each other directly.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerRelationShip.Player
member.summary: Represents the relationship a player has with themselves.

member.name: T:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerStatus
member.summary: Defines the connection and activity status of a player in the game.
member.remarks: This enum tracks the current state of a player's connection and participation in the game session. It helps manage player lifecycle and determine appropriate game behavior based on player availability.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerStatus.Open
member.summary: The player slot is available but no player has connected yet.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerStatus.Connected
member.summary: The player is actively connected and participating in the game.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerStatus.Afk
member.summary: The player is connected but currently away from keyboard (inactive).

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerStatus.Disconnected
member.summary: The player has lost connection but may reconnect.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerStatus.Left
member.summary: The player has permanently left the game session.

member.name: T:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerUnitRelationShip
member.summary: Relationship between a player and a unit

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerUnitRelationShip.MainUnit
member.summary: If the unit is the main unit of the player.

member.name: F:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Enum.PlayerUnitRelationShip.Player
member.summary: If the unit owned by the player.

member.name: T:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player
member.summary: Represents a player in the game, managing team affiliation, main unit control, scene presence, and multiplayer functionality.
member.remarks: Player is a core entity in the game system that represents human players, AI controllers, and system players. It manages the relationship between the player and their controlled units, team membership, scene presence, and network communication. Each player has a unique identifier and is associated with a controller type (human user or AI). Players can own units, switch between scenes, and participate in team-based gameplay. The Player class integrates with the networking system for multiplayer scenarios and provides event-driven updates for client-side state synchronization. It also handles visibility and relationship calculations between different players based on team affiliations and neutral status.
member.summary: Player类对UI属性的IPropertyOwner实现 核心属性操作功能在GameCore中，客户端设置功能在TriggerEncapsulation中作为扩展方法

member.name: M:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of this player including ID and team information.
member.returns: A formatted string describing this player.

member.name: P:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player.Scene
member.summary: Gets the scene where this player is currently located.
member.value: The scene containing this player.
member.remarks: The player's scene is determined by their underlying view player's scene assignment. This affects what entities the player can see and interact with. On the client side, this value is unreliable unless you are fetch the scene of the local player. It may always return the default scene for other players, as you don't have this information of other players

member.name: P:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player.MainUnit
member.summary: Gets or sets the main unit controlled by this player.
member.value: The primary unit under this player's control, or null if no main unit is assigned.
member.remarks: The main unit is typically the player's avatar or primary character. On the server, setting this property updates the underlying view player's main actor reference. On the client, this property is read-only and updated through network synchronization.

member.name: M:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player.GetRelationShip(GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player)
member.summary: Determines the relationship between this player and another player.
member.param: The other player to determine relationship with.
member.returns: The relationship type between the two players.
member.remarks: Relationships are determined based on team membership and neutral status. The hierarchy is: Self > Team Member (Ally) > Enemy > Neutral. Neutral players are considered neutral to everyone except themselves.

member.name: P:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player.IsNeutral
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether this player is neutral.
member.value: True if the player is neutral; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Neutral players are not considered enemies by other players and have special relationship rules. On the server, setting this property updates the underlying view player. On the client, this is synchronized from the server.

member.name: P:GameCore.PlayerAndUsers.Player.ControllerSetting
member.summary: Gets the controller type setting from the player configuration.
member.value: The configured controller type for this player.

member.remarks: 瞬态协议用于传输不需要持久化的临时数据，如视觉效果、音效触发、临时状态变化等。 这些消息通常具有即时性，不需要重传或状态同步。

member.remarks: 此接口结合了字节序列化、协议处理和游戏类注册功能，为瞬态消息提供完整的处理框架。 实现类型必须是非托管类型以确保高效的序列化性能。

member.name: T:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene
member.summary: Represents a game scene that contains entities, effects, and provides spatial operations for game world management.
member.remarks: Scene is a fundamental container for all game objects within a defined game world area. It manages entity lifecycle, spatial queries, pathfinding, and scene loading/unloading operations. Each scene has a unique identifier and can be loaded or unloaded dynamically based on game needs. Scenes support advanced spatial operations like circular, rectangular, and cone-based searches for entities, making them essential for AI, combat, and interaction systems. The scene system integrates with the engine's view layer for rendering and physics, while providing game-logic abstractions for entity management and spatial relationships.

member.name: E:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.OnLoadStart
member.summary: Occurs when the scene starts loading.
member.remarks: This event is fired at the beginning of the scene loading process, before any entities or placed objects are created. It's useful for systems that need to prepare for scene content.

member.name: E:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.OnLoadEnd
member.summary: Occurs when the scene finishes loading.
member.remarks: This event is fired after the scene and all its content have been fully loaded and initialized. It indicates that the scene is ready for gameplay and all placed objects are available.

member.name: P:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.Size
member.summary: Gets the size dimensions of this scene.
member.value: A Vector2 representing the width and height of the scene in world units.
member.remarks: The scene size determines the valid coordinate space for entities and operations within the scene. Size is cached for performance and retrieved from either the game data configuration or the view scene.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.Load
member.summary: Loads this scene and all its content.
member.returns: True if the scene was successfully loaded; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method initiates the scene loading process, which includes loading the underlying view scene and triggering all associated loading events and placed object creation.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.Unload
member.summary: Unloads this scene and cleans up all its content.
member.returns: True if the scene was successfully unloaded; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method destroys all entities and effect persists in the scene, then unloads the underlying view scene. It ensures proper cleanup of all scene resources.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.AddEntity(GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity)
member.summary: Adds an entity to this scene's entity collection.
member.param: The entity to add to the scene.
member.returns: True if the entity was successfully added; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method is used internally to register entities with the scene when they are created or moved into the scene. Entities must be properly registered to participate in scene operations.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.RemoveEntity(GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity)
member.summary: Removes an entity from this scene's entity collection.
member.param: The entity to remove from the scene.
member.returns: True if the entity was successfully removed; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method is used internally to unregister entities from the scene when they are destroyed or moved to a different scene. Removed entities will no longer participate in scene operations.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.GetEntities(System.Func{GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Gets all entities in this scene, optionally filtered by a predicate.

member.returns: An enumerable collection of entities that match the filter criteria.
member.remarks: This method provides access to all entities in the scene with optional filtering. It's useful for systems that need to process specific types of entities or entities meeting certain criteria without spatial constraints.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.GetMorphs``1(System.Func{GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity,``0})

member.param: A function that transforms entities to the desired type or returns null.
member.returns: An enumerable collection of successfully transformed entities.
member.remarks: This method is useful for type-safe entity processing where you want to extract specific types or aspects of entities. For example, getting all units, or all entities with a specific component type.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.Scene.AddEffectPersist(GameCore.Execution.EffectPersist)
member.summary: Adds an effect persist to the scene's collection for lifecycle management.

member.returns: True if the effect was added; false if the target is an entity (handled elsewhere).

The radius of the search circle.
An optional filter to apply to found entities.

The height of the rectangle.
An optional filter to apply to found entities.

member.name: T:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint
member.summary: Represents a three-dimensional point within a specific game scene, implementing targeting and positioning interfaces.
member.remarks: ScenePoint is a fundamental structure for representing positions in the game world. It combines 3D coordinates with a scene reference, ensuring that all position operations are scene-aware. The structure implements ITarget to participate in the targeting system and provides comprehensive spatial operations including distance calculations, angle computations, and coordinate transformations. ScenePoint supports pathfinding integration on the server side and ground height queries on the client side. It serves as the primary position representation throughout the game systems for entities, effects, and spatial queries.

The scene that contains this point.

member.summary: Initializes a new ScenePoint with the specified 3D coordinates and scene.
member.param: The 3D position in the scene.
The scene that contains this point.
member.remarks: The Z coordinate is extracted and stored separately while X and Y are used for the 2D vector.

member.name: E:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.OnPositionChangingStart
member.summary: Occurs when position changing starts (not applicable for scene points).
member.remarks: Scene points don't change position, so this event is never fired. The event handlers are implemented as no-ops for interface compliance.

member.name: E:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.OnPositionChangingEnd
member.summary: Occurs when position changing ends (not applicable for scene points).
member.remarks: Scene points don't change position, so this event is never fired. The event handlers are implemented as no-ops for interface compliance.

member.name: F:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Scene
member.summary: Gets the scene that contains this point.
member.value: The scene reference for this point.

member.name: P:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Constrained
member.summary: Gets a constrained version of this point that is clamped within the scene boundaries.
member.value: A new ScenePoint with coordinates clamped to valid scene bounds.
member.remarks: This property ensures that the coordinates are within the valid range of the scene, preventing out-of-bounds positions. The X and Y coordinates are clamped to [0, Size-1].

member.name: P:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.ApproachableTarget
member.summary: Gets the approachable target interface for this scene point.
member.value: This instance as an approachable target for pathfinding.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.op_Addition(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint,System.Nullable{GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint})
member.summary: Adds two scene points together, combining their coordinates.
member.param: The first scene point.
The second scene point, or null.
member.returns: A new scene point with combined coordinates.
member.exception: Thrown when the scene points are in different scenes.
member.remarks: If y is null, returns x unchanged. Otherwise, both points must be in the same scene. The resulting point has the sum of coordinates and Z values.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.PathWayPointsTo(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint)
member.summary: Calculates the pathway points from this scene point to the specified destination for ground unit pathfinding.
member.param: The destination scene point to calculate the path to.
member.returns: An enumerable of scene points representing the pathway, or null if no path exists or scenes differ.
member.remarks: This method returns pathway points only if the current scene and the destination scene are identical. If the scenes differ, the method returns null. If no pathway can be found, the method also returns null. The pathfinding is optimized for ground units and considers terrain obstacles and navigation constraints.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Distance(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint)
member.summary: Calculates the 3D distance to another scene point.
member.param: The other scene point to calculate distance to.
member.returns: The 3D distance between points, or float.MaxValue if in different scenes.
member.remarks: This method calculates the Euclidean distance in 3D space including the Z coordinate. Points in different scenes are considered infinitely far apart.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Distance2D(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint)
member.summary: Calculates the 2D distance to another scene point (ignoring Z coordinate).
member.param: The other scene point to calculate distance to.
member.returns: The 2D distance between points, or null if in different scenes.
member.remarks: This method calculates the Euclidean distance using only X and Y coordinates, which is useful for ground-based movement and area calculations.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Distance2DSquared(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint)
member.summary: Calculates the squared 2D distance to another scene point for performance optimization.
member.param: The other scene point to calculate distance to.
member.returns: The squared 2D distance between points, or null if in different scenes.
member.remarks: Squared distance is computationally cheaper as it avoids the square root operation. This is useful for distance comparisons where the actual distance value isn't needed.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Offset(System.Numerics.Vector2)
member.summary: Creates a new scene point offset by the specified 2D vector.
member.param: The 2D offset to apply.
member.returns: A new scene point with the applied offset.
member.remarks: This method creates a new instance with modified X and Y coordinates. The Z coordinate and scene reference remain unchanged.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Offset(System.Single,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a new scene point offset by the specified X and Y amounts.
member.param: The X offset to apply.
The Y offset to apply.
member.returns: A new scene point with the applied offset.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.Lerp(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint,System.Single)
member.summary: Creates a new scene point interpolated between this point and a target point.
member.param: The target scene point to interpolate towards.
The interpolation factor between 0.0 and 1.0.
member.returns: A new scene point at the interpolated position.
member.remarks: Linear interpolation creates smooth movement between two points. An amount of 0.0 returns this point, 1.0 returns the target, and 0.5 returns the midpoint.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.PolarTo(GameCore.BaseType.Angle,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a new scene point at the specified angle and distance from this point.
member.param: The angle to move in.
The distance to move.
member.returns: A new scene point at the calculated position.
member.remarks: This method uses polar coordinates to calculate a new position relative to this point. If distance is zero, returns this point unchanged. The calculation is performed in 2D space.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.PolarToRadian(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a new scene point at the specified radian angle and distance from this point.
member.param: The angle in radians to move in.
The distance to move.
member.returns: A new scene point at the calculated position.
member.remarks: This method performs the polar coordinate calculation using radian angle representation for precise mathematical operations. It's used internally by the Angle-based method.

member.name: M:GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint.AngleTo(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint)
member.summary: Calculates the angle from this point to the target point.
member.param: The target scene point to calculate angle to.
member.returns: The angle to the target, or null if points are identical or in different scenes.
member.remarks: The angle is calculated using the arctangent of the Y and X coordinate differences. If the points are at the same position, no meaningful angle can be calculated.

member.name: T:GameCore.ScopeScript
member.summary: Provides access to recently created game objects for scripting and debugging purposes.
member.remarks: This class maintains references to the most recently created instances of various game object types. It is primarily used in debugging scenarios, script execution contexts, and situations where immediate access to newly created objects is needed without explicit reference passing. The references are updated automatically by the creation systems and should be used promptly as they may be overwritten by subsequent object creation.

member.name: P:GameCore.ScopeScript.LastCreatedUnit
member.summary: Gets or sets the most recently created unit in the game.
member.value: The last created unit instance, or null if no unit has been created yet.
member.remarks: This property is automatically updated whenever a new unit is created through the game's unit creation systems. It provides convenient access for scripts and debugging tools that need to reference the most recent unit without maintaining explicit references.

member.name: P:GameCore.ScopeScript.LastCreatedActor
member.summary: Gets or sets the most recently created actor in the game.
member.value: The last created actor instance, or null if no actor has been created yet.
member.remarks: This property is automatically updated whenever a new actor is created through the game's actor creation systems. Actors represent visual and interactive elements in the game world, and this reference is useful for immediate manipulation or attachment operations.

member.name: P:GameCore.ScopeScript.LastCreatedItem
member.summary: Gets or sets the most recently created item in the game.
member.value: The last created item instance, or null if no item has been created yet.
member.remarks: This property is automatically updated whenever a new item is created through the game's item creation systems. Items represent collectible objects, equipment, and other inventory entities in the game world.

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Sphere
member.summary:
球体 - 直径100（半径50），原点在球心
适用场景：球类、星球、泡泡、弹珠、敌人
默认颜色：红色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Cube
member.summary:
立方体 - 边长100，原点在底面中心
适用场景：箱子、建筑块、方形障碍物、容器
默认颜色：橙色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Cylinder
member.summary:
圆柱体 - 底面直径100（半径50），高度100，原点在底面圆心
适用场景：柱子、管道、炮筒、圆形建筑
默认颜色：灰色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Plane
member.summary:
平面 - 边长100的正方形，原点在几何中心
适用场景：地面、墙壁、平台、水面
默认颜色：棕色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Cone
member.summary:
圆锥 - 底面直径100（半径50），高度100，原点在底面圆心
适用场景：箭头指示、山峰、帽子、警示标志
默认颜色：黄色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Capsule
member.summary:
胶囊 - 直径100（半径50），总高度200，原点在底端圆心
适用场景：角色身体、子弹、药丸、玩家
默认颜色：蓝色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Pyramid
member.summary:
方形金字塔 - 底面边长100，高度100，原点在底面中心
适用场景：古代建筑、堆积物、尖顶建筑
默认颜色：沙黄色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Torus
member.summary:
环形（甜甜圈） - 外径100，高度40，原点在几何中心
适用场景：甜甜圈、轮胎、环状装饰
默认颜色：紫色

member.name: F:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShape.Wedge
member.summary:
楔形 - 底面边长100，高度100，原点在底面后端中心
适用场景：坡道、楔子、斜面
默认颜色：绿色

member.name: T:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig
member.summary: 基本几何形状配置数据（用于GameData序列化）
member.remarks: 这个配置类用于在GameDataUnit中定义单位的基本几何形状。 当单位在客户端创建时，会根据这些配置自动生成相应的形状表现。

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.Shape
member.summary: 形状类型

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.Offset
member.summary: 相对于单位原点的偏移位置

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.Scale
member.summary: 形状的缩放比例

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.Rotation
member.summary: 形状的旋转角度（欧拉角，度数）

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.ColorMode
member.summary: 颜色模式

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.ColorTheme
member.summary: 颜色主题

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.CustomColor
member.summary: 自定义颜色（如果设置，将覆盖颜色模式）
member.remarks: 当此字段不为null时，将忽略ColorMode和ColorTheme设置， 直接使用指定的自定义颜色。

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.AttachToRoot
member.summary: 是否附着到根单位
member.remarks: true：附着到单位本身的原点 false：附着到前一个创建的形状（用于复合形状）

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.Tag
member.summary: 形状标识符，用于后续管理和引用
member.remarks: 可以用于后续通过代码动态修改或移除特定的形状。 如果为空，将自动生成一个基于形状类型的标识符。

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.Priority
member.summary: 形状优先级（数值越大越后创建，影响附着顺序）

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.EnableCollision
member.summary: 是否启用碰撞检测
member.remarks: 注意：基本形状通常只用于视觉表现，不建议启用碰撞。 单位的碰撞应该由其他系统管理。

member.name: M:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.IsValid
member.summary: 验证配置的有效性
member.returns: 配置是否有效

member.name: M:GameCore.Shape.Data.PrimitiveShapeConfig.GetEffectiveTag(System.Int32)
member.summary: 获取有效的标识符
member.param: 形状索引，用于生成默认标识符
member.returns: 形状标识符

member.remarks: 该系统使用框架的IGameClass自动注册机制，在游戏启动时自动创建所有基本形状的 GameDataModel和GameDataActorModel数据。支持多种颜色主题和尺寸配置。

member.name: T:GameCore.Shape.Region
member.summary: Abstract base class representing a geometric region within a scene. Provides a common interface for region types (such as circles and rectangles) to define spatial properties, containment logic, and entity queries within the region.

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Region.Position
member.summary: Gets the position of the region, typically representing its origin or anchor point.

member.name: P:GameCore.Shape.Region.Center
member.summary: Gets the center point of the region.

member.name: M:GameCore.Shape.Region.Contains(GameCore.SceneSystem.ScenePoint)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified point is contained within the region.
member.param: The point to check for containment.
member.returns: true if the point is within the region; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:GameCore.Shape.Region.Contains(GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity)
member.summary: Determines whether the specified entity is contained within the region.
member.param: The entity to check for containment.
member.returns: true if the entity is within the region; otherwise, false.

member.name: M:GameCore.Shape.Region.FilterEntities(System.Func{GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity,System.Boolean})
member.summary: Returns all entities within the region that satisfy the specified condition.
member.param: A predicate to filter entities; if null, all entities within the region are returned.
member.returns: An enumerable of entities within the region that match the condition, or null if none found.

member.name: M:GameCore.Shape.Region.FilterEntities``1(System.Func{GameCore.EntitySystem.Entity,``0})
member.summary: Returns all entities within the region that can be transformed to the specified type and satisfy the given condition.
member.typeparam: The target type to which entities are transformed. Only entities for which the returns a non-null value are included.
member.param: A transformation function that takes an and returns a instance or null. If null is returned, the entity is excluded from the result.
member.returns: An enumerable of instances representing entities within the region that match the transformation condition, or null if none are found.
